awd_titl_txt: The impact of co-infection on host and parasite population dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will improve the ability to predict how disease causing parasites affect their host (animal) populations and whether disease transmission is altered when different species of parasite occur within the same individual host, a process known as co-infection. Parasites, by definition, use energy from the hosts they infect in order to reproduce and spread to new hosts. While previous research has made great strides in understanding how traits of single parasite species affect disease transmission, predicting interactions among co-infecting parasites remains a research frontier. When two parasite species occupy the same host, the outcome of infection may not be the same as when each parasite occurs separately, due to interactions between the parasites. This project will evaluate the consequences of co-infection for host health, the spread of disease, and host population biology, using a model organism that impacts food safety in stored grains. Additionally, this project will provide scientific training and mentoring to high school, undergraduate, and graduate students; identify factors that affect the agricultural control of pests and pollinators; and implement an outreach project to recruit women from under-represented minorities to fields in STEM.

The researchers will use mathematical models and laboratory experiments to evaluate the effects of parasite co-infection on a flour beetle (Tribolium castaneum) model host system. The first objective is to determine the mechanisms through which co-infecting parasites interact in order to evaluate the impact of co-infection on parasite growth rates and host infection outcomes. The researchers will manipulate host nutrient acquisition, alter parasite infection routes, and quantify the impact of co-infection on host immune response using next-generation mRNA sequencing. This objective will elucidate the importance of top-down (immune-mediated) versus bottom-up (resource-mediated) ecological interactions for structuring parasite communities within the host. The second objective is to quantify the impact of infection order and the strength of within-host interactions on the transmission of each co-infecting parasite to new flour beetle hosts, connecting within-host to epidemiological processes. The final objective is to develop mathematical models of Tribolium population biology that predict how co-infecting parasites influence host population dynamics and parasite persistence, based on the experimental data. This project will provide novel and generalizable insight into the wider ecological context of co-infection and the impact of dynamical feedback across scales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Parasites exploit the energetic resources of their hosts and cause damage to their tissues and organs, raising the risk of host morbidity and mortality and influencing the growth and decline of host populations as the parasites are transmitted among individuals. Hosts in nature, however, are rarely infected with just one species of pathogen or parasite. Parasites that co-infect a host can compete with each other for energy or make it easier for each parasite to exploit the host by influencing immune responses, ultimately impacting infection outcomes for the host and the probability of transmission for each parasite. This project integrated experimental, transcriptomic, and theoretical methods in an insect model system to understand how interactions among parasite species within the host influence parasite transmission and ability of infected host species to compete against others in nature.

In feed mills and stored grain facilities around the world, flour beetles (e.g. the Red Flour Beetle Tribolium castaneum and Confused Flour Beetle T. confusum) infested stored products and cause substantial economic damage. T. castaneum can reproduce faster than T. confusum and so tends to be more abundant when the two species compete directly for resources. Classic experiments from the 1940s and 1950s demonstrated that the presence of single parasite, however, could flip the outcome of competition among these two species, allowing T. confusum to win because T. castaneum is more susceptible to the parasite. With these results in mind, we chose to conduct our experiments in these flour beetle species.  

To understand how the presence of one parasite species could influence the establishment and success of another parasite, we conducted a series of experiments using two classes of parasites: eugregarines, protozoan parasites that inhabit flour beetle guts but do little direct damage, and Bacillus thuringiensis, a bacterial pathogen that quickly kills insects. We manipulated the quality of flour beetle food to alter the resources available for both hosts and parasites, and measured host survival, development time, and metabolite levels in uninfected, single-infection, or co-infected hosts in larval and adult life stages. We also performed RT-qPCR and mRNA-seq on these hosts to measure changes in the expression of immune and metabolic genes associated with infection status in each host life stage. We discovered that larval and adult beetles and beetles of each species share many common immune responses to infections, but also exhibit some differences that could influence coinfection outcomes. We also discovered that in both host species, eugregarine infection results in the depletion of carbohydrate and lipid resources within the host and suppresses important immune genes in the gut, resulting in higher host death rates when they became subsequently infected with the bacterial pathogen. We also measured the relative number of parasites present in single and co-infected hosts, but so far have not detected an impact of coinfection on parasite burden in this system. These results are important because they demonstrate that both energetic and immune responses are affected by co-infecting parasites and could act together to influence infection outcomes and parasite transmission.

Recalling the classic experiments that demonstrated the sensitivity of host flour beetle species competition to parasite infection, we wanted to explore whether coinfection, relative to single infection, was likely to reinforce these outcomes or reverse them. Therefore, we built a mathematical model of flour beetle species competition when each species could be infected or coinfected by parasites. The results of our model suggest that infection-induced mortality is a particularly important parameter to measure in wild populations, because if coinfection enhances mortality then it could promote species coexistence, while if coinfection reduces mortality to a focal infection in even one species, a wide variety of outcomes are possible.

The completed work has resulted in six publications to date, with further papers in preparation. The project contributed to the research training of three postdoctoral scholars, seven graduate students, and eight undergraduate students, including 13 women and four URM students. In addition, we designed an interactive module for high school students, entitled “Parasites: the struggle within,” to teach students about parasite epidemiology and coinfection. We ran this activity at a local high school and at the Tennessee Women in Science, Tech, Engineering, and Research Conference (TWISTER) in Nashville, TN.
